abstract.text: An object that manages the synchronization of local and remote record data.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use

to handle your app’s CloudKit sync operations and benefit from the performance and reliability it provides. To use the class, create an instance early in your app’s launch process and specify a database to sync. Thereafter, and depending on good system conditions, the sync engine will periodically push and pull database and record zone changes on the app’s behalf. To participate in those sync operations and to provide the engine with the changes to send, create a type that conforms to
and assign an instance of it to the engine’s configuration. You can have multiple instances of
in a single process, each targeting a different database. For example, you may have one syncing a person’s private database and another syncing their shared database.

Because periodic sync relies on good system conditions — adequate battery charge, an active network connection, a signed-in iCloud account, and so on — the engine’s sync schedule is indeterminate; if you need to sync immediately, like when you need to ensure your app has the most recent changes before continuing, use the
and
methods.

The sync engine uses an opaque type to track its internal state, and it’s your responsibility to persist that state to disk and make it available across app launches so the engine can function properly. For more information, see
and
requires the CloudKit and Remote notifications entitlements. For more information, see
and
Don’t use
to sync your app’s public database.
A sync engine requires you to tell it about any changes to send, which you do by invoking the
and
methods on the engine’s

property. If there are no scheduled sync operations when you invoke these methods, the engine automatically schedules one. Database changes don’t require any additional input, but the sync engine does expect you to provide the individual record zone changes — in batches — and return them from your delegate’s implementation of
. After the engine sends the changes, it notifies your delegate about their success (or failure) by dispatching
and
events.
By default, a sync engine attempts to discover an existing

for the associated database and uses that to receive silent notifications about remote record changes. If the engine doesn’t find a subscription, it automatically creates one to use. On receipt of a notification, the engine schedules a sync operation to fetch the related changes. When that operation runs, the engine dispatches a
event to your delegate. As it receives fetched changes, the engine dispatches
and
, accordingly. After the operation finishes, the sync engine notifies your delegate by dispatching a
event. You handle all dispatched events in your delegate’s implementation of
A sample code project for
is available on GitHub here:

abstract.text: Store structured app and user data in iCloud containers that all users of your app can share.
A subscription that generates push notifications when CloudKit modifies records in a database.
An object that manages the synchronization of local and remote record data.
A type that configures the attributes and behavior of a sync engine.
Describes an event that occurs during a sync operation.
A type that provides information about an update to the sync engine’s state.
An event that indicates the database fetch is done.
An event indicating there are fetched database changes to process.
An event indicating there are fetched record zone changes to process.
An event indicating a sent batch of database changes.
An event indicating a sent batch of record zone changes.
An event indicating an imminent database fetch.
A set of options to use with a fetch operation.
Describes an unsent database modification.
Describes an unsent record modification.
A type that contains the record changes for a single send operation.
A type that describes a single attempt to send changes to the iCloud servers.
A set of options to use with a send operation.
An object that manages the sync engine’s state.
Adds the specified database changes to the state.
Adds the specified record zone changes to the state.
Describes the reason for a sync operation.
Cancels any in-progress or pending sync operations.
The associated database.
Fetches pending remote changes from the server.
Creates a sync engine with the specified configuration.
Sends pending local changes to the server.
The sync engine’s state.
An interface for providing record data to a sync engine and customizing that engine’s behavior.
Tells the delegate to handle the specified sync event.
Asks the delegate to provide the next set of record changes to send to the server.
Explore the various options you have for using iCloud to store and sync your app’s data.

doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/C.title: Deciding whether CloudKit is right for your app

abstract.text: Manipulate records on-device and save changes to the server.
Use subscriptions and change tokens to efficiently manage modifications to remote records.
Share one or more records with other iCloud users.
Indicate the background services your app requires to continue executing in the background in iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, visionOS, and watchOS.
Share user or app data among multiple instances of your app running on different devices.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
